title: Here’s what Boston meteorologists are saying the day after the historic blizzard
author: John Waller
bullets: Boston's season snowfall exceeds 60 inches, the highest since the 2015 snow blitz.
T.F. Green Airport in Warwick, RI potentially set a state record with 37.9 inches of snow.
Boston recorded 17.1 inches of snow, surpassing the daily record for February 23.

title: 4 maps predicting totals from Wednesday morning’s snowfall
author: John Waller
bullets: Boston expecting light snowfall Wednesday from a clipper system, with 1-3 inches in most areas.
Snow will turn to rain in lower elevations after mid-morning due to temperature changes.
Higher elevations might experience up to 3 inches of snow, starting after midnight Wednesday.

title: Dozens of volunteers canvas Boston for homeless people outside as blizzard bears down on the city
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Pine Street Inn outreach teams canvassed Boston during a blizzard, providing blankets and rides to shelter for the homeless.
The nor'easter dumped over 16 inches of snow, with winds and low visibility, prompting emergency efforts to aid the homeless.
Pine Street Inn's shelters in Boston accommodated over 660 people, exceeding their 585-bed capacity with extra mats and cots.

title: 50 percent of departing Boston Logan Airport flights canceled Tuesday
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Over 50% of flights out of Logan International Airport were canceled Tuesday due to a powerful nor’easter.
Nearly 1,000 flights were canceled and Amtrak service was suspended between Boston and New York on Monday.
Amtrak aims to restore train service by Tuesday morning but advises travelers to expect potential cancellations.

title: To trade or not to trade? Bruins must make their call with Viktor Arvidsson.
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Boston Bruins are considering trading Viktor Arvidsson, who has 14 goals and 28 points in 45 games.
Arvidsson, acquired for a 2027 fifth-round pick, has been a significant offensive contributor for the Bruins' playoff push.
Bruins face trade deadline decision: retain Arvidsson for playoff hopes or trade him for draft picks amid a roster rebuild.

title: These Mass. schools are closed on Tuesday, Feb. 24.
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Schools across Massachusetts are closed on Feb. 24 due to a snowstorm bringing over 30 inches of snow.
Major districts closed include Boston, Cambridge, Worcester, and Lexington, among others across the state.
Some districts like Athol-Royalston and Littleton report delayed openings instead of closures on Feb. 24.

title: AJ Brown recalls ‘critical’ Mike Vrabel moments that changed hatred to respect
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: AJ Brown's initial dislike for Mike Vrabel evolved into respect after key coaching moments during his rookie year.
Brown recalled Vrabel's tough but motivational approach, improving his performance with the Titans starting in 2019.
Speculation continues around a potential trade of AJ Brown to the New England Patriots, where Vrabel is now head coach.

title: US women’s hockey declines invite to State of the Union, men’s hockey also invited in viral Trump phone call
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: US women's hockey team declined Trump's State of the Union invite due to scheduling conflicts following Olympic gold win.
US men's hockey team, also Olympic gold medalists, received a similar invitation from Trump for State of the Union.
NCAA and PWHL commitments prevent women's players from attending; men's team participation in D.C. remains unconfirmed.

title: Patriots cut running back Antonio Gibson to save cap space
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots released running back Antonio Gibson, clearing over $3 million in salary cap space.
Gibson suffered a torn ACL in Week 5 of the 2025 season and had no guaranteed money for 2026.
Gibson contributed 644 rushing yards, 212 receiving yards, and was a top kick returner with a 28.5-yard average.

title: Yes, this storm is officially a blizzard. Here’s what meteorologists want you to know.
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Meteorologists declared a blizzard in parts of Massachusetts and Rhode Island, including Boston and Providence, as of Monday morning.
A blizzard requires 35 mph winds, visibility of 1/4 mile or less for three hours, and doesn't require active snowfall.
The National Weather Service warns of power outages, whiteout conditions, and hazardous travel due to high winds and blowing snow.
